data.title: Viewing derived class variables while hovering the cursor over a base class pointer (C++)
data.body:
Is it possible to view the member variables of a derived class during debugging by hovering the cursor over a base class pointer that points to an object of the derived class. 

Curious to know if visual studio code or debuggers in general support this feature.

Currently, visual studio code only shows the base class variables when I hover the cursor over the base class pointer pointing to a derived class object.

Any help is greatly appreciated.

- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. 
2.

data.title: "Execute the restore command to continue" messages in large projects cycle continuously
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone an AspNet Core repo with lots of projects (like aspnet/Mvc).
2. Open that folder in VS Code and wait for all the messages reading `There are unresolved dependencies from 'project'. Please execute the restore command to continue.` to appear.
3. From the command line run `dotnet restore`.
4. Observe the rapid scroll of the restore messages.

data.title: Javascript formatter: space-before-function-paren
data.body:
We use [space-before-function-paren](http://eslint.org/docs/rules/space-before-function-paren) in our eslint rules for readability.  I'd like an option to format to this behavior 

- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type ```function foo () { }```
2. Format the code (if it doesn't auto-format)
3. Code is formatted to ```function foo() { }``` with no mechanism to override

data.title: Inconsistent handling of CRLF -> LF between TextEdit and TextEditorEdit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra (10.12.1)

- Easiest to demonstrate with HookyQR.beautify installed

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project folder.
2. Add a `.jsonbeautifyrc` file with
```javascript
{"eol": "\r\n"}
```
3. Create a json file, with content, that includes several lines. eg:
```javascript
{
    "beautify.language": {
        "js": {
            "type": [
                "javascript",
                "json"
            ]
        }
    }
}
```
4. Set the document line end to **LF**
5. Format with the beautify command (`F1->Beautify file`) -> No extra lines are produced.
6. Format with "Format Document" -> ***An extra line will be produced for every existing new line***.

You can repeat step six over and over to add extra lines to the new extra lines.

This is caused by inconsistent handling of new lines in document edits between `TextEditor.edit` (returning a `TextEditorEdit`) and `TextEdit.replace` (and its siblings, I'm assuming - returning a `TextEdit`).

The beautify command calls `activeTextEditor.edit` to provide the changes. This works correctly, changing CRLF to LF when required.

Format Document (and Format Selection) call `TextEdit.replace` (as the callback requires an array of `TextEdit`s to be returned) and changes CRLF to LFLF, generating extra lines.

*Also, as a side note:* it would be helpful if `FormattingOptions` included an `eol` property.

data.title: File Search - Improve performance of file search
data.body:
Part of #55.

We will focus on simple text search. Regex text searches might be more difficult to optimize and are used less often than simple text searches. We will initially explore our options (e.g., refining our own implementation, command line tools, text search libraries/engines).

We will include full-text search libraries/engines in our investigation and see if any of these can do simple text searches while at the same time open the door for also supporting a more natural 'fuzzy' text search at a later time.

The goal is raw search performance with library size (if any) and disk usage of an index (if any) being potential trade-offs.

data.title: Improve support for Javascript in HTML
Review themes in response to `vscode-textmate` changes
Investigate possible sceanrios that can get crashes reported without metadata
data.body:
VS Code uses the [electron crash reporter](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/crash-reporter.md) to report crashes.
The crash reporter is initialized to send the below in each crash report

- The crash dump
- The crash time
- Platform, product and Company name
- VS Code SessionId, Version and Commit corresponding to the Version.

We have been noticing crash reports from Mac in huge numbers that have just the dump and none of the rest of the metadata outlined above. 

This task is to track the scenarios where such a thing is possible

data.title: Improve accessibility of diff editor (do not only use color)
data.body: Improve accessibility of the diff editor (side by side and inline view). Currently we are just using color (red/green) to indicate addition/deletion/changes, we may want to use `+` and `-` as indicators as well.

data.title: Configure Explorer to show and distinguish generated/derived files
data.body:
VS Code lets you exclude files and folders from the Explorer with the `files.exclude` setting. This is useful for hiding generated or ignored files while you're working. Sometimes, however, it's useful to see if your workflow is generating the expected files and folders.

I'd like a feature that lets me configure rules for a new setting, perhaps something like `files.generated` or `files.derived`. Files and folders that match a rule would appear "faded" or "grayed out" in the Explorer, indicating that they are distinct from the source code. VS Code should also warn me before directly editing a "generated/derived" file, since I should be editing the source file it came from. Another setting could toggle this feature, determining whether generated/derived files are treated the same way excluded files are.

Alternatively, this feature could be tied into the existing `files.exclude` setting by adding the above-mentioned setting to toggle how excluded files are treated.

data.title: Ability to expand all collapsed regions
data.body:
In the past it was nice to just scroll and read about all possible settings.
Right now they are all collapsed and one need to click a lot of boxes to open them.
Right click to see the option to expand all would be very useful

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/20220684/76d0f0ae-a7fc-11e6-8920-d1759a7b8811.png)

data.title: Ability to add Activity Bar inside Side Bar
data.body:
Just adding this request as suggested by @bpasero in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1105#issuecomment-259721480

For example setting:

`workbench.activityBar.location = "sideBar"`

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/20220215/a3f94ad8-a7fa-11e6-912d-3f65d5e7c7eb.png)

Benefit would be that `Cmd+B` would hide both at the same time - right now one need to hide them separately - they are both related so would make sense to be able to dock Activity Bar inside Side Bar - especially for someone who wants more horizontal space (when working with multiple editor groups)
